comments.commentBody: Any publicity is good publicity, and Sanders did not get nearly enough.

Why would the giant news corporations give space and time to Sanders who is directing negative attention to their bias and corruption of our democracy? As dismaying as it is to witness the rise of Trump and Hillary, it is heartening to see the youthful enthusiasm for Sanders. Elizabeth Warren will carry on the spirit that both of them have summoned forth.

" . . .a plurality of people 18 to 29 years old said that the social media was their most helpful source for learning about the 2016 presidential election."  Proof that these people are then very poorly informed.

Social media, which projects a billion voices with a billion opinions and counterpoints, is in fact a much richer source of information. News media outlets, on the other hand, are controlled by a handful of corporations with agendas of their own, so I'd say, you and your ilk are the ones who are poorly informed.

Exactly. And we're supposed to trust this naive, truly uninformed band of Bernie supporters.

Quite revealing to learn that most of what they know they glean from social media, which basically is nothing more than hearsay, opinion, or worst of all-spin. Just look at these comments.

And most of these individuals didn't even know Bernie Sanders from Colonel Sanders a year ago. It wasn't until word got out there was a politician who was pushing for free college education they even took and interest in Sanders, and then by attrition, they probably figured this guy would be getting all student loan debt forgiven. And most of those that are threatening to cancel their subscription probably got their subscription for free anyway when a friend signed up and passed along the free subscriptions that came with the one they purchased. That's the way the Millennials live. On the cheap.
Exactly. Social media is a self imposed bubble. We tend to listen only to those with whom we agree.
It's true that Hillary receives a lot more coverage than Sanders.  But at least half of it is negative, while nobody ever says anything bad about Bernie,

Re: "nobody ever says anything bad about Bernie"

You mean like "he's quixotic", "he's a raving extremist", "he's your dotty uncle you must ignore", "he couldn't possibly win a single primary, a fortiori a presidential election"? Nobody ever says those sort of bad things about Bernie? Must be two Bernies running for the Democratic nomination then. The other Bernie is continually ridiculed.
Why do you suppose that is, jas?

Thanks because "the media" -- including the hugely influential and dominant NYT -- decided a long time back that Hillary was going to be the nominee, no matter if the voters liked it or not.

Since Sanders had no chance, why cover him? Why waste the time? Had he pulled out a miracle upset victory, oh my -- then they would have been out with sharp knives. His lack of military service, his honeymoon in the Soviet Union, his lack of any career or job until he was 40 and elected Mayor of Burlington, etc.

But he served a role, which was to "prove" Hillary had some opposition. I guess he did that. Bye, Bernie.

Although I'm certain you believe you've presented a fair and accurate assessment of the factors involved in the media blackout of Bernie Sanders, Mr. Blow, you and your newspaper have proven time and again to be nothing more than an integral part of the establishment which has worked against the Vermont senator at every turn.

NYT readers have been greatly disturbed by the Bernie blackout that has existed right here in the good 'ole NYT and we have posted numerous comments protesting said blackout in your column Charles.

Surely you are not suggesting that because other MSM vendors have neglected Bernie that you/NYT are not so bad!
Allow me to summarize: mainstream media failed again.

They haven't failed. They're doing exactly what they do. They propagate on behalf of the establishment. The tell the big lie over and over again and drown out the truth. "Saddam has nukes and he's going to bomb America just like he did on 9/11."

Fortunately, it appears that the people have started to notice that the establishment isn't very good at government. They have noticed that the infrastructure is crumbling, health care costs are soaring, wars never end, inflation is destroying the value of their money,* and the jobs they have always had no longer exist.

The establishment may be successful in oppressing the people for one or two more election cycles, but eventually this thing is going to blow. This conclusion is dictated by the laws of physics.
________________________
* The government doesn't include the cost of housing, food, health care, or energy in its inflation calculation. Convenient, right?

Negative coverage often requires, if not, demands a response, providing an opportunity for a candidate to further explain her or his policies. Sanders ought not be denied this opportunity, nor should the public be denied insightful critiques - rather than the grossly reductive (perhaps even Trump-like) school-yard dismissiveness that has sadly characterized the Times' coverage of Sanders.
Ironically both BBC and Al Jazeera covered Bernie's excellent speech, as well as speeches and comments by all of the candidates.

Bob.... And also RT TV which now features Ed Schultz at 8pm, who used to have a nightly show on MSNBC, before he was xxld, that dealt with the topics that Sanders has introduced into the campaign.
Also France 24 has a nightly debate show that is focusing a lot on the US election.
Real "news" sources. And the Guardian too does a pretty good job of covering news from the US. Go figure, it always takes an outsider...

http://www.alternet.org/election-2016/watch-bernie-sanders-speech-networ...

Link to the Ariz. speech. Worth a listen.

I am 47 now but even as a young man I gravitated to the New York Times because it seemed a trustworthy and progressive new source. The lack of attention to the Bernie Sanders campaign has called that into direct question.
The Times has never claimed "progressive". Never. Sorry you were confused.

I finally got so exhausted by the propaganda that I canceled my subscription.

At least the Wall Street Journal is candid about its mission.
People want to be with the one who seems to be winning.  Media create that perception, just look at Trump.
More biased coverage. Is winning 49% of the vote being trounced? Sanders gets trounced in the South. Only there.

Bernie has done very well despite the lack of coverage.  The lack of coverage, and the skepticism of the media, has made it doubly difficult for him to introduce himself and his ideas to the general public.  I have long said that the more people see Bernie the more they like him, and the more they respect his main thesis.  He has done a great service this year, not only bums long Hillary a better candidate, but also by focusing on the core US problem of income/wealth/power inequality - something none of the other candidates don't talk about or even get.I hope that Bernie has shown that many Dems oppose the Clinton's desire to turn the Democrats into Republican-lite.  The younger voters "get" Bernie. They are the future. So is getting more info via social media.  Too bad traditional media closed their eyes to what is going on

There is no satisfying any candidate.  News media bias is now the norm.  All media, may it be online, television or hard copy is a business.  What generates business gets the coverage.  That being said, maybe Sander's platform can use some scrutiny because it's really very revolutionary but not necessarily a platform the Democrats can bring into the General election if they want to win.  The Youth vote often disappears until the next Presidential election.  Most probably didn't even bother to check the candidates on their local elections and just focused on Sanders on the ballot.  There are Primary candidates in Senate races that could determine the make up of the next Congress.

MelanioFlaneur: "Most probably didn't even bother to check the candidates on their local elections and just focused on Sanders on the ballot."
Do you have any evidence to back up this comment, or is it just satisfying your belief that Sanders' supporters are not serious about the political process?
Don't worry Mr. Blow his protesters in Chicago got ample coverage.....enough said.

Conrad, you can close your eyes to Black Lives Movement, you can pretend that Occupy did not happen, you can pretend people have no complaints about blacks being incarcerated unjustly. These movements are a reality. You can choose to ignore them, but for every single one like you, there is my daughter who will save grocery money to send $10 to BLM or organization for black struggle, for CA and FL farm workers. People like my daughter represent the future, they are listening and they are enaged.

Nice try, Mr. Blow.

https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/how-the-new-york-times-sandba...

Thank you, rtj of Massachusetts. Your reference to the Rolling Stone article is well worth reading. I have often noticed how NYT articles change from one click to the next. Makes me wonder ......

https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/how-the-new-york-times-sandba...

rtj, thank you for that; it should have been a real eye-opener.

So why am I not in the least surprised?

"Clinton’s voters may be less likely to show up to rallies, or post on social media or be serial commenters who commandeer comments sections, but they do show up to vote."

And this is why Clinton is winning in the primaries. Sanders' supporters, who are primarily engaged in social media and have the time and energy to attend political rallies, are blindsided. The right wing has kept quiet about Bernie, because they want him to be the nominee, he's easier to destroy. And even though he's a curmudgeon, he's much more thin-skinned than Hillary Clinton.
Hillary Clinton to the right of republican president Einsenhower, and possibly Nixon. Good luck, America! War, War, War and depression, except for Wall Street.

It has long been true that part of the Media's superficial coverage of elections is its focus on polls.  Not just talking them but using them to determine who gets more coverage.  What is different this years is the Trump eclipse.  The dominance of coverage by Trump, over and over it was said he did not have to advertise because of all the free Media.  The Press which isn't to smart to begin with should be embarrassed.

Where was this article three months ago? NYT and the media knowingly sabotaged Sanders campaign and it is infuriating to say the least.  Bernie is a once in a lifetime candidate. You had your chance American Media, and you blew it.

Les W: Free college tuition (at public universities) is not "giving someone something for nothing." It is investing in society, investing in young people, and not wasting precious talent because higher education has become unaffordable.

By the way, tuition-free college is achievable in reality. It's the reality over here in Germany, for example. It's sad that in your reality, people are nasty, greedy and "willing to tromp on others." It doesn't have to be that way.

Wow. A 'once in a lifetime' candidate. Really?

I'm guessing that if the media really had reported on Sanders early and heavily, he would be doing far worse than he is now.

The thing with Sanders is that there is no there there.
This is an opinion piece by a columnist, not an article. That distinction is important in assessing coverage.

Almost the entire mainstream media marginalized Sanders from the beginning.

This is funny in a way because 2016 is an unusual year in which the voters are rebelling against the establishment. From the very beginning only two candidates tapped into that zeitgeist: Sanders on the left and Trump on right.

But selling papers and online advertising matter more to today’s media than thoughtful discussions of thing like income equality. So the loud mouth bully has gotten the lion’s share of the media attention and he’s almost certainly going to be the GOP nominee.

I am a Sanders supporter who has been carefully and meticulously following and listening to the anger of the citizenry over the last eight or nine months. The discontent on both the right and left is unlike anything I have seen in the past 40 years.

I expect the overwhelming majority of the GOP leadership to cave and support Trump in the self serving hope that his victory will protect and even advance their own personal career and financial interests.

Clinton's base of support is, by contrast, exceedingly thin. Nor can it be overstressed that her most powerful message in November will be “I am better than the alternative.” If Clinton was once "likable enough", she isn't anymore. Indeed the level of vitriol felt against Clinton by those on the right and center (and with Sanders’ presumed defeat some of the left as well) is beyond frightening.

Needless to say, I am anticipating a Trump victory in November.

We are not talking innuendo, we are talking voting record and recorded comments. Hillary has changed her tune on so many issues, and her record of accomplishments so thin, that yes, this criticism is warranted.

The idea that anyone can predict Clinton's strength in November based upon her strength in the Democratic primaries (many of which were closed) strikes me as bizarre.

I have zero problem accepting that Clinton has sewn up the Demcratic nomination. Part of the reason for my post was to warn folks that I actually think she is very vulnerable IN NOVEMBER.

This has absolutely nothing to do with my favoring Sanders. It has everything to do with my not wanting to see Trump become president.

But rather than acknowledge that Secretary Clinton may have a tough road after the convention, the folks commenting here accuse me of being a Trump supporter.

THIS is exactly why Clinton is at risk of losing-- because you all think someone like me is the enemy for saying what ought to be a common sense concern. If you think the Sandernistas have been hard on Clinton, you are clearly completely clueless for what is coming after the conventions. Moreover, unlike Sanders, the GOP will have hundreds of millions in PAC money to spread their far more hateful messages.

As to NSH, taking Sanders out of the picture, of course HRC is the best candidate. But that doesn't mean her current campaign has her on a trajectory to win.

Finally, while I share FSMLives! presumed abhorrence with likability being a factor in choosing a president, it unfortunately influences a great many voters. (Remember the November election is not going to be determined by the folks who read the New York Times every day.)

One last thought which nobody will read either.

The whole point of my original post was what I had observed from reading tens of thousands of blog posts. Maybe they weren't scientifically chosen (the vast majority were found here at the New York Times) but they were passionate and as near as I could tell in most cases sincere. THAT was the primary reason for my making my prediction.

Nobody here even addressed the fact that my conclusion that Trump was likely to win was based on listening to actual voters and hearing their anger.

I cannot say strongly enough, if the Democrats run this campaign by looking only from the top down and not from the grass roots up, they will be making a huge mistake.

Millions have contributed to Bernie Sander's campaign. Millions more attend his town halls. Why you ask. Because we deeply detest Hillary Clinton for abandoning the core values of the Democratic Party. It is well documented that Hillary and Bill Clinton have sold out the middle class for personal wealth and to fund the Clinton "Foundation".

Hillary's $675,000 in for speaking to Goldman Sachs tell the whole story while the $14 million earned after leaving the State Department cast her allegiances in cement.

As a group, if we can't vote for Bernie to be president, we certainly won't vote for Hillary. Perhaps voting for Donald Trump will force the DNC to play fair with Democratic candidates next time instead of letting Debbie Disaster run a black ops campaign.

Bill -- Bernie is losing the vote.  The people voting in the Democratic primaries don't agree with your claims.  So go vote for Trump.  Stop acting like you are anything other than that.  We knew that's what most of you are.
The women in your lives will know who to thank when they lose their reproductive rights. Nice going.

You know, if you Bernie supporters spent half as much time building Bernie up instead of trashing Hillary, you might garner more support.

Outside of pointing out that millions have supported Bernie, you present zero positives for why I, or anyone else, should be supporting Bernie.

Instead, you bring out the trope about how Bill & Hillary have 'sold out' the middle class to fund the Clinton Foundation. You say it's 'well documented' but provide no source material. Maybe it's 'well documented' on far left liberal blogs or far right blogs but it's not well documented in the real world.

And again with the infantile 'If Bernie isn't the nominee, I'm voting Trump' nonsense. You would destroy all the progressive achievements of Obama and possible destroy the country out of spite.

You truly cannot call yourself progressive if you are willing to vote for Trump.

Aside, the DNC owes Bernie about $1,000 worth of support. That's all he helped fund raise for them last year. I would think he has gotten far more in value from the DNC than $1,000.
I was just going to link to the same piece. It does seem that the NYT is clearly in HR's pocket.as the RS piece points oat, some of the NYT coverage could have been written by HRC.

If anything the media should point out over and over Bernie's lack of concise policies he can enact. Folks should see that he is not credible in his ability to get much done. It should be pointed out he is pulling a fast one over these young voters, it's a shame.
Great reply Frank, from a fellow 60 year old.
The difference is that Bernie has spent years pontificating and haranguing in Congress with what exactly to his credit and our profit?
Well I'm in my late sixties with advanced degrees in STEM. Sanders hasn't pulled the wool over my eyes. Perhaps Clinton has pulled the wool over yours.

Ever since The Times editorial board wrote that it was supporting Hilary, it has become as though each and every columnist lost all free will and had to support that editorial.
Your first line says that Hilary TROUNCED Bernie. Unfair for weeks.
Isnt winning 5 states being "trounced"?
Not even "since" then...they have been writing glowing opinion and *news* articles about Clinton well before.

Hillary won 3,713,033 votes on March 15th. Bernie won 2,821,094 votes.

Hillary bested him in all five states by 891,939 votes.

More importantly, Hillary won 371 delegates to Bernie's 271. She won 100 more delegates than Bernie increasing her total to 1,139 to his 825, a difference of 314 delegates.

By all metrics, yeah, one could say that Bernie was, indeed, trounced.
like on carson the demagogue...i kind of wanted to say, like from men on film, cept men on gop, you and bruni, "don't get mad'.
